{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3533848,"name":"Jaco Xia","username":"jxia","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/b77776/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T03:25:29.582Z","cooked":"

Hi, this is quite the silly question, but our team is facing massive difficulty calculating the correct gear ratios for our mechanisms. From our prior understanding, we just wanted our mechanism under it‚Äôs intended load to be behind the peak of the power curve to ensure that the motor is being used efficiently. This is based off my experience in VEX motor calculations, but clearly it is very different in FRC. Here is what that would look like (using the JVN calculator)

Motor Calculation1262√ó519 76.4 KB

However, using this ratio in real life turned out to be iffy. We used this ratio for the pivot of our algae mechanism (I am on team 694, Stuypulse).

Stuypulse 694 Algae Mech637√ó634 103 KB

Also we weren‚Äôt sure if the ratings for the Kraken on the website are actually of use, unless if we understood it wrong.

X60:

  • 1100+W peak power* (413W @40amp)
  • 6,000RPM
  • 87% max efficiency (@30A)*
  • Greater than 84% efficiency between 15A-40A
  • 7+Nm stall torque*

Previously, we would just use the torque (loaded) of the system and divide it by half of the stall torque. This would give us a ratio that put our motor directly at the peak of the power curve; then we chose a ratio that was slightly more, and used the JVN calculator to validate our ratio. Is the data that the motor is rated for correct? Or am I missing a step in the process? Do I use 7Nm as the stall torque? Or do I use a smaller value based off a specific current that makes sense in the context of the mechanism?

In our testing, 8:1 was not sufficient. Is there a better way to calculate a gear ratio? I am slightly aware that some teams do their calculations with a specific voltage in mind for their mechanism ‚Äì or is that outdated/wrong?

How does voltage/current affect the process in calculating a gear ratio?

Thank you for reading

‚Äì Jaco X.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T03:26:24.180Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":171,"reads":316,"readers_count":315,"score":918.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"Jaco Xia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60895,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"694"},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/1","custom_user_title":"694","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3533863,"name":"Matthew K","username":"superdude311","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/superdude311/{size}/230653_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T03:31:59.174Z","cooked":"

I would use ambcalc or recalc and put in their definition of a kraken, as then you don‚Äôt need to go around looking for WCPs questionable marketing of it‚Äôs power. Note that your loaded current draw is 103 amps, and while its not the worst to go over the breaker limit, exceeding 2 times goes against what the datasheet says is ok for FRC-match timeframes. So work the ratio to get that current draw way lower. Then your loaded time to move will make more sense.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T03:31:59.174Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":265,"readers_count":264,"score":83.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"Matthew K","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55172,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"barn2robotics alumni"},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/2","custom_user_title":"barn2robotics alumni","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533899,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T04:11:31.255Z","cooked":"

Anand‚Äôs bit here is good:

PSA: Your Motor Curves Are Wrong (A Whitepaper About Current Limits) CD-Media: Papers
I spent the last few days working on a short whitepaper that shows the effect of stator and supply current limits on motor performance. Both limits drastically change the shape of motor curves from the ‚Äútheoretical‚Äù parabolic power curves that most people are familiar with and are commonly published, so I thought it would be interesting to share. You can read the full whitepaper here: PSA Your Motor Curves Are Wrong.pdf (917.4 KB) Some images from the calculator and whitepaper are shown belo‚Ä¶

TLDR: for things like your pivot, that don‚Äôt move too fast, you‚Äôre current-limited almost all the time (a good thing), so you need to use current-limited torque values (around 1.5 Nm,. much less than the 7 Nm spec).

You‚Äôll want to think about balancing gravity, and also the torque required to accelerate your mechanism to move it quickly. So maybe you want, say, double the gravity torque.

Also, for simple pivots like this, you could counterbalance the moving part, to save the motor the effort of fighting gravity.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T04:11:31.255Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":257,"readers_count":256,"score":101.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OdmpYBSMWzM","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":2},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/psa-your-motor-curves-are-wrong-a-whitepaper-about-current-limits/477010","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"PSA: Your Motor Curves Are Wrong (A Whitepaper About Current Limits)","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533980,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T08:16:13.223Z","cooked":"

I would use AMB account because it correctly accounts for dynamics. Recalc doesn‚Äôt do deceleration so AMB is better in most cases, but doesn‚Äôt do arms so if your arm is super heavy, recalc is more accurate (but still doesn‚Äôt do decel, if you want to do both correctly, you will have to make your own calc). JVN and older calcs do not account for system dynamics which are extremely important, especially for fast systems or systems with little external loads.

I would plug in everything as accurately as as you can into AMB calc and then use what it says, rounding up. If there is a bunch of uncertainty in the paramters, I would add some more margin of safety, but if you are pretty sure in the paramters, the fact that the breaker doesn‚Äôt pop instantly can be your margin of safety.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T08:16:13.223Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":195,"readers_count":194,"score":49.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://ambcalc.com/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"AMB Robotics Calculator","clicks":25}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534118,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T15:05:21.956Z","cooked":"

This topic is a bit of a honey pot for me, I apologize for the repetition.

Please don‚Äôt blindly punch numbers into some form and blindly use the output. FRC is an opportunity to learn things, and one of those things is the physics of motors and simple machines. If you haven‚Äôt seen these topics in your own physics curriculum, talk with someone who has: they can walk you through it in about 20 minutes. Ask your instructor, I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôd love to talk with a student with real interest.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T15:05:21.956Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":165,"readers_count":164,"score":48.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534188,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T15:28:40.985Z","cooked":"
truher:

and one of those things is the physics of motors and simple machines. If you haven‚Äôt seen these topics in your own physics curriculum, talk with someone who has: they can walk you through it in about 20 minutes.

Its not so simple because its a dynamic system with both non-linear constraints and potentially non-linear dynamics and the relevant concepts are usually taught in a 2nd or 3rd year college course, and even then, non-linearities are rarely discussed. Because of this, a time-stepper is the easiest and best way to solve these types of problems, and any of the analytical ways of solving these are even more inaccessible. This is doubly true when FRC vendors can‚Äôt properly document the motors for the life of them, which requires you to know what you are doing to get the actual constants you are looking for.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T15:28:40.985Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":38.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534190,"name":"Arjun Ohri","username":"arjunorsmth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arjunorsmth/{size}/263909_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T15:30:41.584Z","cooked":"

Out of curiosity, are there are any go to resources you recommend for learning this stuff? I don‚Äôt think any of my mentors will want to get on a call at 2AM after a full day of CAD to teach me about thisüò≠.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T15:30:41.584Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":26.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"Arjun Ohri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53190,"username":"truher","name":"joel truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66645,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5667 Captain/Driver/Design/Sponsorships Lead"},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/7","custom_user_title":"5667 Captain/Driver/Design/Sponsorships Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534228,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T15:59:13.784Z","cooked":"

@arjunorsmth re: learning resources, not off the top of my head. many sources are either too simple (e.g. ignoring current limits) or too complex (e.g. requiring calculus). i bet one of your mentors would be happy to chat with you during the day.

@Alex_Y re: model complexity, this is another thing that FRC is trying to teach: all models are predictive approximations. it‚Äôs certainly true that there is endless fascinating complexity in everything around us. it is certainly false that every bit of this complexity is critical to every prediction we might want to make. in the case of a single motor and a single rotating joint, where the prediction is ‚Äúit will move approximately where and when i want it to,‚Äù the only tools you need is the motor curve i pointed out above, and high-school physics. in this specific case, the missing knowledge seems like the behavior of the current limiter.

if you want to predict the motion very precisely at very high speed, then yeah, you need to understand more of the details of the system (e.g. how the controller behaves, the physical characteristics of the battery, the type and temperature of the grease used in the bearings, the drag produced by the bow shock formed by the mechanism as it approaches the speed of sound, etc).

understanding what you need to know, and what you can ignore, to solve a specific problem, is, I suppose, the key thing that FRC is trying to teach all of us.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T15:59:13.784Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":123,"readers_count":122,"score":44.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534718,"name":"Erik Boyle","username":"Ekcrbe","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ekcrbe/{size}/221615_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T21:14:25.949Z","cooked":"

Sure, but there‚Äôs an 80/20 rule at play here. You can still walk your students through reading the limited motor curves and solving the quasi-steady-state system from an energy perspective and get 80% of the educational value for 20% of the difficulty (or less, honestly). What does it look like under a current limit? What does it look like after it comes down from the current limit? We don‚Äôt know exactly when that will be, but we can design the form of the behavior. Those calculations can be very comprehensible to high schoolers and are of great value to give them some insight into how the dynamics of electromechanical systems function.

Then it‚Äôs very fair to tell them that the math to get true time-to-setpoint calculations is much harder, but we have numerical analysis tools to help us not have to rederive everything from scratch, and they can refine our coarse hand estimates. After all, isn‚Äôt that what we do in real engineering anyway?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T21:14:25.949Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":88,"readers_count":87,"score":62.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"Erik Boyle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50219,"username":"Alex_Y","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17480,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads"},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/9","custom_user_title":"Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534758,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T22:02:14.411Z","cooked":"

The DC motor system equation is marvelously simple and can be understood by high schoolers without a lick of calculus. It‚Äôs also a good opportunity to teach your students what a ‚Äúlinear combination‚Äù is.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T22:02:42.846Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":77,"readers_count":76,"score":15.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492410,"topic_slug":"selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/selecting-gear-ratio-motor-math/492410/10","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534844,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T23:58:34.092Z","cooked":"
truher:

the missing knowledge seems like the behavior of the current limiter.

More importantly, you are missing voltage saturation. At the speeds that FRC teams like to run mechanisms, they are quite often voltage saturated (in addition to also being often current saturated) to the point that any model that doesn‚Äôt account for the saturations is inaccurate enough to not be very useful due to severely overestimating the (highly non-linear) performance of the motors. No simple physics 1 equation will get you out of this because you get less and less torque avaliable as you accelerate, which makes everything non-linear and we are back to using time-steppers again to solve these problems.

see, just talking about the problem helps to illuminate the important details.

in this case, I think you may be using the word ‚Äúsolve‚Äù differently than I am. for most students, ‚Äúpredict the minimum-time achievable trajectory‚Äù is not the problem they‚Äôre trying to solve, and I don‚Äôt think it should be. a good problem to solve would be ‚Äúdevelop intuition for electrical and mechanical systems‚Äù.
